segments.text: At that time of the years of the war, early stages, the B-17 began to take head-on attacks by the German fighters in Europe, and they were being shot down.
They were losing a lot of B-17s.
As a matter of fact, the whole daylight bombing concept was in jeopardy.
General LeMay at that time was a division commander, I think a full colonel, and he was devising tactics and formations for the B-17s to combat just such tactics.
So we acted as the fighters against formations of B-17s in the Orlando area in Florida.
and made head-on attacks at B-17s.
And boy, I tell you, at times it got hairy.
It was worse than combat.
Did it come in that close?
Oh, yeah.
Well, as a matter of fact, when Bob Houck, I think his name was H-O-U-K, I believe that was his name.
I'd have to refer to my diary.
He hit a B-17 head-on with a P-47, and he was flying between a number...
two engine and the fuselage head on.
Well, it was simulating exactly the tactics that the B-17 were confronted with in Europe.
And did the B-17 probably went down, too?
Did it kill that group?
No, I think they bailed out.
I think it was a result of that that they divided the chin turret for the B-17.
when they put the guns, .50 caliber turrets in the chin of the B-17 forward firing.
It was that type of tactics we experimented with, and it was quite realistic.
And as I say, I think it did good in devising tactics, and particularly training the new boys that were taking groups and going overseas, expanding the Air Force.
Then it was at that time, doing that type of work, that in early 43, when I was tabbed to go to Washington to be interviewed by General Arnold for a possible job to Moscow with Herman.
And of course, I didn't know about what the purpose was at that time, except I was told to report to Washington.
So now we're approaching the start
Russian episode.
Well, I want to find out about tactics.
Did you change tactics because of the way that the Germans were coming head on, or was it just basically putting another mount on the B-17?
It was, I think it was a change a little bit of the formation of the B-17.
It probably was a tighter formation with more B-17s up front, a flatter B, if you will, plus the Chin turret, new firepower for the front.
Now, in fighter tactics, we stressed, just strictly fighter tactics, air-to-air combat.
We had to stress a difference in the European theater versus the Far Eastern theater.
And what was that?
In the European theater, it was exactly the reverse of what it was in the Far Eastern theater.
As I told you before, you know, the Zero was for maneuverable.
It was strictly hit-and-run and dive-out tactics in the Far East.
Whereas in Europe,
our aircraft could maneuver easily and maybe in some cases outmaneuver the Focke-Wulfs and the Messerschmitts.
And the what?
Messerschmitts.
And Messerschmitts.
Particularly when we got the P-51 Mustang.
So, in other words, in Europe, you tango with them, fight them, maneuver with them.
In the Far East, no.
What did you think was the quality of the German aircraft?
I've never flown one of them, but talking to the pilot and of course reading about their, no doubt the German aircraft was a fine airplane.
Were they superior to ours in any way?
Initially it was the forest period of B-40.
We found that out in North Africa.
As a matter of fact, that's one reason.
Flying Tigers got the P-40.
The British said it was, you know, it just wasn't good enough.
And that's the reason they developed the Spitfire series.
And then that's the reason we went to the Mustang.
And then the old jug, the turbo-cubitar aircraft that had a lot of power at altitude.
Towards the end of the war, our aircraft were easily comparable, of course.
But I always go back to the
the bottom line criteria that was the quality of our pilots.
Pilots.
The quality of our pilots.
And compare them with the Japanese pilots and the German pilots.
One of those against the other one?
Yeah.
I think the German was superior.
But I don't have personal experience in fighting with the German.
And compare ours with those two.
Equally or better, I don't thank any pilot.
I still am the old.
I think the American fighter pilot is the best in the world.
Would you agree today that they are?
Well, I don't know the quality of... Or when you left the service?
Oh, when I left the service, yeah, I still had confidence we were the greatest.
Of course, you know, combat experience, we've had more actual war experience later than any of the other nations.
Of course, the Germans, I mean, the Russians have probably had their experience in Afghanistan, but practically against what?
Nothing.
Now, what about training?
As far as the training, you were training men down there to be combat pilots, basically.
How good was the training?
Then or now?
In Orlando, then.
Oh, superb.
Tops, you couldn't beat it.
That's the reason we were killing some pilots, because it was realistic.
But did that bother you?
No.
Matter of fact, I think it's a sin to send a pilot over to war and not have him trained.
Yeah.
I think that's wrong.
But who knows what the necessities might require.
We may not have the time.
Now, why do you think that you were chosen to go up and see General Arnold?
I'm not sure, but this is an interesting story, and let me tell you about it.
I got a call at my fighter base in Florida to report to General Arnold's office, oh, it gave me two or three days leeway, but at nine o'clock one morning, and I did so, and it was on the basis of
General Arnold wanted to talk to four pilots of Lieutenant Colonel rank with combat experience that had flown a lot of different airplanes and who could use his head.
That's the only criteria.
Is that what they said?
Right.
And General Peabody, at that time, commanding the School of Applied Tactics,
told me personally that it seemed like I fitted that description.
So he recommended me to General Arnold, and I got my P-47, my jug, and flew up to Washington.
And there were four of us lined up in General Half Arnold's office.
This was in the Pentagon.
And he went down the line just asking
one after the other.
Would you like to go overseas?
And one of the boys' answer was, well, sir, I just got back and I'd like to get more familiar with my baby daughter, which incidentally was exactly my case.
He said, okay.
He asked another guy, would you like to go overseas?
He said, if you give me a fighter group of P-51, I'll go right now.
And third one, I forget what he asked him and what the answer was, but it's somewhat along the same line that it came to be.
And he says, Bond, would you like to go overseas?

And to the best of my knowledge, to be very exact, I think I said, well, General, I think you remember that you promised that if I went back overseas, you told General Chenault I could go back with him.
And he looked at me rather straight and very thoughtfully thinking, turned around, walked over to the window and gazed out the window a few minutes.
Turned around, leaned back, pulled his blouse apart, put his hand on his hips.
I rank Chenault.
And then grinned.
And after that, we dismissed us as well.
I said, I'll let you all know tomorrow morning.
The next morning, all four of us reported in at 9 o'clock.
And you had no idea what this was for.
Had no idea what it was for.
But now, one out of the four said, yes, sir, I'll go any place, any time.
Under certain conditions, see.
Everybody had conditions.
Everybody had conditions, including mine.
And of course, the general arm personally made the decision.
The secretary said, Colonel Bond, the general would like to see you.
Well, maybe he said that.
You know, all four of us were sitting there.
All four of us knew then, of course.
It's pretty obvious it was going to be me.
So I went in, and I can't recollect everything we talked about, except that I think he did start out and said, this job isn't for generals at all.
But he said, no.
tell you what it is, and I want this kept absolutely secret.
You can't talk to anybody about it.
Including your wife?
Including, well, obviously.
He said, you're not supposed to, you know, this is like a wartime secret.
You just don't tell anybody.
And that, you know, I immediately began to be tense and wondered what in the world is this?
Well, I knew it's overseas because that's the question he asked me.
He said, you're going to go to Russia with that Mr. Herm.
Do you know Mr. Herm?
No sir, I don't.
And of course, then he explained to me what it would be for sending a military mission to Moscow for closer cooperation with them.
And you're going to be Ambassador Herrmann's aide for me.
You're going to be my aide for Ambassador Herrmann.
You're going to have the Air Division part of a mission we're going to put in Moscow for cooperation with Russia to win this war against Europe, against Hitler.
Also, were you the pilot for Herrmann?
Yes.
That was another part of the- See, that's another part.
Flown all types of airplanes.
And obviously what had in mind, we were going to pick out an airplane, make it into as plush an airplane as we could for the ambassador to go back and forth to Russia.
It turned out to be an old converted B-24, which was a liberator in an air transport model with a bomb bay taken out.
bunks and chairs and put it in, which I'd never flown.
I'd never flown a B-24, but I had to be checked out of here immediately as part of the job.
Well, that's he explained it.
He said, do you think you can do it?
And of course I said, yes, sir.
And he said, okay, you go in and see, of course, General Vandenberg.
He was a brigadier general at that time.
And who served with me came chief of staff.
Sure did.
And worked with him.
So from then on, of course, that's what I did.
And about, uh,
Well, what were your thoughts?
Did you want to go, or did, just tell me.
Oh, yes, I was very excited.
This was completely a new experience for me.

I was very excited about it, and I, of course, wanted to immediately tell my wife about it, Doris, but I was reluctant because of the secrecy of the thing, and she was still in Orlando, of course, and then I thought about my
new little baby daughter, and that this is going to be tough on her, it's going to be hard, but I want to go.
And of course, I'm in the military, if he's chosen me and General Arnold, the Chief of Staff of the Air Force, then gee, I ought to go.
And I knew this would be, it was a feather in my cap, I knew it would definitely enhance a career.
I'd be
in a new area that I'd never been exposed to before in a diplomatic video with a very important person, Mr. Harriman.
I'd read about him, but I didn't know him.
And here dealing with the Russians, a country I'd never been to before.
It was somewhat like my experience when I knew I was going to go to China, a new adventure.
So I was very excited.
And eventually, of course,
But on the back, I had to explain to my wife.
I didn't tell her until about a week later what my job was going to be.
Nobody knew what it was going to be.
But of course, I made it.
I was released from duty in my job in Florida.
And I was taking trips every day to various places.
And one of the biggest requirements immediately was to get checked out in the B-24 in a base in Tennessee.
so that I could fly the Ambassador over in his airplane, the Liberator.
In the meantime, it was being converted and pushed up inside at another air base.
Did you keep the gun mounts on it?
No, no, no.
This is strictly an air transport version.
Was it to fly singly or with a fighter escort?
Oh, no, no.
Strictly, you know, we would never get in the combat area with the airplane.
In effect, it was an air transport command type aircraft.
But I was to be the pilot.
I had a crew.
Did you make it nice and plush?
Oh, yeah.
Well, as plush as you could one of those airplanes.
The Air Force wasn't choosy about that.
You knew under wartime conditions, as long as it was a dependable airplane.
Was it?
Yes.
Oh, yes.
Turned out to be a good old airplane.
And how fast did it go?
It's not like a B-17.
It's not quite as fast as a B-17.
It's more of a little bit harder to fly.
It was a lumbering type aircraft, wallowed a lot in the air, but you could use an automatic pilot.
It had turbo superchargers on it to fly well at altitude, but of course it wasn't pressurized.
If you get above 12,000 feet, you have to have oxygen to be comfortable, so we never fly very high.
No need to, except when we fly over the mountains from Tehran, when we take off to go over the mountains mainly south of the Caucasus area.
But I think if I ever got there, it was about 13,000 feet for about 15, 20 minutes.
How about your crew?
I selected my own crew.
I had a co-pilot, navigator, radio operator, and crew chief.
We had our base maintenance support out of an air base in Cairo.
Where'd you keep the plane?
In Moscow?
what we called a central airport at that time.
It was, if you will, the main terminal airport for the city of Moscow.
I don't even know why it's called today.
Who maintained the flight?
My crew maintained it.
Well, we just had the crew chief and, of course, the radio operator.
But when we had major maintenance requirements or inspections, we'd take it down to the air base in Cairo.
I forget the name of that base.
It was the United States American Air Force Base.
How about as far as keeping it in a hangar and just housing the airplane?
How did you get along with the Russians on that?
Well, we didn't have a hangar.
We kept it parked outside.
They didn't have a hangar on that air base at the time to take care of that bigger airplane.
Russian guards were on the airplane 24 hours a day.
Even I had trouble getting to the airplane.

I'd have to call through my interpreters from the embassy out to the airport and through an interpreter and tell them, arrange for a particular hour that Colonel Bond, incidentally, within a couple of months after I was in Moscow with the Airmen, I was the most important colonel, and they'd tell the Russian
security forces that Colonel Bond and his crew would be out to his airplane by a certain time, and you know, they have to wait to get to the airplane, and the guard would be told this.
In one occasion, we had a little trouble in communication, and apparently the guard wasn't told and didn't know, and the guard would not let me get to the airplane.
As a matter of fact, he pulled his rifle off his shoulder and pointed it at me and said, near, near.
And the only thing I could do was take the crew back to the
operation building and through the interpreters, getting through the security forces, and they had to change the guard.
They didn't change the orders to the guard.
They changed the guard and gave him new orders.
And I want to tell you at this point, I can say that we in America didn't know what security was, in my opinion, until we met and became compliant with Russian security.
It was just absolutely ironclad.
There's just no comparison in our security, in my opinion, compared with the Russian security.
And this perfect example was the Tehran conference, where President Roosevelt and Stalin and Prime Minister Churchill met.
And of course, they had these three type of security forces all over the city.
And when I had to get out
to my airplane at the airport to do some maintenance on it.
While they were meeting, I had to go from the American camp on one side of the city to the city of Tehran to get to the airport.
I had to pass through some of these guards, and I met American, British, and Russian guards.
When I came to the American guards, typical, well, who are you?
Stop me, and so forth.
Challenged me in my jeep, and I told him, and well, I showed him my identification and all, and he, OK, go ahead.
Went to the British Guard.
He was a little bit more strict.
And finally agreed, OK, go ahead.
But I went and met the Russian Guard.
And yet, I was not required.
I was not permitted to go past them.
He didn't care who I was.
I had to turn around, go back to the camp, and then through telephone and communications with proper security forces, get a new pass to go through the Russian Guard.
That is typical of the difference, in my opinion.
It's just absolutely iron bound.
What's your opinion on that?
Is it favorable, unfavorable?
Oh, I was impressed.
These people, when they say secure, they mean secure.
Whereas a little bit of give and take, you know, an hour, it's just... And in my opinion, I think this is still true.
In my subsequent days in Russia, you know, came to...
Many meetings attended with Russians and the diplomats at the highest level in the Kremlin right on down to the military forces in the field.
I took several trips to the front.
And it was always the same thing.
I was impressed with their security.
Okay, now let's go back to get ahead of ourselves.
Yeah, let's go back.
The plane is outfitted, and then what, you met Ambassador Harriman?
I had several meetings.
various times with the Ambassador.
Before he left America?
Oh yes, and we discussed he wanted to know me better and I wanted to know him better and we immediately got along great.
I admired him from the very outset.
Why?
He impressed me as a real diplomat.
He talked quietly and softly and
His mannerisms, I'll never forget, is he would continually put his hands in his coat pockets.
His coat was buttoned, and he had a mannerism.
He was always going to put his hands in his coat pockets, and he'd stand away for a while, maybe walk back and forth and talk to you a little.
Then he'd take his hands out.
Then when he'd get to another real serious point, he'd take that pose again.
I, it's funny, I still remember this.
And I've since seen pictures of him.
You know, he's some around 80 some odd years old now.
And I notice he still does this.
I see him in TV.
He wasn't going to take his wife.
He was taking his daughter.
And he introduced me to her, a young girl.
She was unmarried.
A very pleasant person.
And both of them spoke more with the English brogue.
Mm-hmm.
I never will forget this.
When he first spoke to me, I thought, gee, he sounds English.
And Kathy, his daughter, definitely had the English bro.
And I think this might stem from, you know, he'd had a lot of experience and time in the diplomatic service in England.
He was a very wealthy man, you know, a very wealthy man from the New York area.
and he had had dealing with Russia before, and incidentally he was, you know, this was the ambassador.
We didn't have an ambassador at that time.
I think there was an admiral, there was an admiral who had been on sort of a semi-ambassadorial staff.
Acting, acting ambassador.
Who?
Acting ambassador.
We had Joseph Davies,
Yeah, he was one.
But they weren't assigned strictly.
Well, maybe they were.
And then Ehrman came about.
Ehrman was going to be the ambassador, and he was going to stay in the embassy in Moscow.
And we had, I remember General Arnold telling me this, and the ambassador also reaffirming it to me, and even General
We had three missions from the Air Force viewpoint.

One was to try to open up new air transport command aerial routes into Moscow from up around the north, from England to Murmansk, then down into Leningrad and Moscow, and from the south up through Cairo across to Tehran and up through
Vladivostok into Moscow.

And also from the east, from across the United States up through Canada, Alaska, and across the Siberian area, which was really a challenging task, to open up air routes across there and use them more freely.
The main thing, use them more freely.
And I put that in quotation marks.
Then the second was to...

develop and generate a freer exchange of weather information and the primary purpose of this of course was for the far east operation against japan because we needed weather reports for weather forecasts we needed the weather reports from the siberian outposts west of japan in order to make a valid forecast for particularly the wind the law
You know, in our bombings of Japan is when we first learned about the so-called high altitude jet streams.
It got as high as 200 miles an hour, you know, at times.
And this is the first time that we ran into these high altitude operations.
And we need more information for this.
Sure.
And the third objective, of course, and which was by far the most important, was to develop some shuttle bases for the bombers

in the ukraine area of russia where we could fly across germany from either italy the 15th air force area or europe the eighth air force area with their b-17 b-24 bomb and land and recover in the shuttle bases in russia
bomb up again and go back and of course it would be continuous 24-hour operations and at the outset it would only be American bombers, B-24s and B-17s.
And initially only B-17s from the 8th Air Force.
Did you have particular areas in the Ukraine that you wanted?
Yes.
I was briefed on all of this.
Every briefing that the Ambassador was given with respect to the Air Force I always attended.
And also General Vandenberg also attended.
And when we first went over, if I remember correctly, I think it was, unfortunately, here again, I didn't keep a diary of my business in Moscow.
I sure wish I had.
But I think it was about the middle of September that we took off for Russia.
And it was for the whole conference.
We know it now as the Hull Conference.
At that time, Secretary Hull was Secretary of State Cordell Hull.
And we took off from National Airport at Washington, D.C.
The ambassador traveled with Secretary Hull on that mission, but I took off in my converted B-24, we called it a C-87, with my crew, and heavily loaded with a lot of...

of communication equipment and two or three army officers from the, I think it was called the Army Security Service at that time, which would be the secure communication equipment that would be installed for the ambassador's use, assuming the Russians would let us do this.
And that was going to be one of the things that Mr.
Hull would establish with Mr. Stalin.
permit us to have our own communications.
You know, diplomatic.
Sure.
And we made the flight by way of Europe.
So Holvo and Harriman did not go in your airport?
No.
I was to meet you.
And you left in October of 43.
September.
September.
Around September of 43.
OK. After about two months of conferences,
In England, we had a lot of briefings.
Oh, I mean, at the Pentagon, and getting to meet Harriman and everything, and getting the plane ready took about two months.
Briefings and all, and getting the airplane ready.
And it was very hectic.
Now, you started out talking about Harriman, and you sort of described him.
I'd like to know a little bit more about him.
You said he was a soft-spoken man, but you never really described his character, or would you
I never really knew much about him at that time except what I had read about him or seen, but my personal observations immediately were those I had just given you.
And of course I learned to know him much better later on.
After you were with him for over a year, how did your evaluation change?
My initial evaluation didn't change very much.
As a matter of fact, I learned more of his characteristics.
He was a
extremely hard worker.
He worked morning, noon, and night.

Many times I would be called over to the embassy, say around eight o'clock in the morning, and he would still be lying in bed with papers all over the bed, still in pajamas, maybe in his breakfast tray next to the bedside.
He hadn't gotten out of bed yet, and he'd probably been working three or four hours.
His aide and interpreter
a Navy lieutenant.
He, I tell you, I don't see how he kept the pace he did.
I've seen him when he was- Do you know his name?
Do you remember his name?
I think his name was, I'm not going to say York, it was another Navy commander.
I can't remember his name.
There's a book written by General Dean called A Strange Alliance, where his name would be in it.
Very fine book, but I don't see how he kept the pace he did.
Harriman was a very demanding man to work for.
I never, he was, to me, he was just
I made me tell Tri, I've got to make a flight to go down to so-and-so, and said, you take care of this, and I'd like to leave about 8 or 9 o'clock or something like that.
Let me know the takeoff time.
That's all I need to know.
And then you were laid on for me.
That's about all he'd tell me.
And every once in a while, I didn't
The more I got to know him, maybe he would add a few comments.
I want to go down and I want to meet and talk with so-and-so, and I've got to get this done, and something like that.
He'd clue me in a little bit more.
But never more than it was necessary just to make me feel as part of the team.
So it did make you feel part of the team?
Oh, definitely, definitely.
And we took, immediately, we took a license to one another.
He had a great respect for me.
And he knew my background with Chenault, and particularly my combat record.
And quite often on the airplane sometime, we'd be sitting and talking, just discussion.
And he'd tell me, get me to tell him some of my experiences.
And very interested in it.
And he had a healthy respect for Chenault.
He considered Chenault quite a hero, and obviously felt the same way about me.
And I knew he liked me.
And as a result, it was easy for me to like him.
We had a great respect for one another.
I had seen him get mad.
I'd seen him pace the floor and actually say to me that this man Molotov, he's crazy.
Crazy.
And he realized he was telling me then some of the problems he had in his relations with the Russians and...
And he would say, now try this, it doesn't involve you.
He said, it doesn't involve you.
And in other words, forget what I'm talking about.
But he was so upset, he was walking back and forth across the floor as a result of a meeting he had had with Mr. Molotov.
That's what he'd say, he's crazy.
Well, obviously, Molotov didn't agree with him, or his demands were just outrageous.
I didn't know what the subject was either.
All I know is that Herrmann was very upset and very disappointed with the discussion he had had with Molotov on some problem.
And was this typical?
I mean, after conversations with Molotov?
This was the only time I've seen Mr. Herrmann visibly upset.
But I do know from stories and others that he had rough meetings with the Russians.
And this goes back to what I was going to tell you this morning, their demanding, arrogant attitude about things that they wanted.
They didn't want things, they demanded things in the area of Lend-Lease aircraft supplies.
And so many supplies we gave them that we saw in a field later on were just wasted.
We gave them so much that they couldn't use it.
In one case, I think- Well, we'll talk about that when you go out on the field.
And when you look at- we'll talk about that when you go out.
But why didn't Harriman take his wife?
Did he ever tell you?
Yes, she had a very bad eye problem.
I think it was glaucoma.
I'm not sure.
She had very bad-
very poor eyesight, and she had to have constant medical care, and apparently she couldn't get it in Russia.
How often would he go home, back to the States?
And you always flown, of course.
I don't think, I don't remember coming back home on one single trip.
He had 13 months.
He may have gone home on one trip by other means, but I'd get him down to Cairo.
My job was to get him in and out of Cairo.
Matter of fact, we did not, I don't believe Ann Bester ever made a trip back to the United States.
I don't even remember us making a trip to England.
We went down to Cairo and Tehran for several conferences.
Now, when you flew down to these places, would he ever come up in the cockpit?
No, no.
I'd go back and talk to him.
You know, the flight from Moscow down to Tehran is around, I think, about four or five hours, four and a half hours, something like that.
Around four hours.
Then the flight from there to Tehran to Cairo is a few hours.
And we had time to talk.
Small talk.
Every once in a while we'd talk about the Russians.
He'd ask me what I think, you know, about the men I'd met, you know, and what did you tell him?
He was never surprised at the things I'd tell him.
I had a respect for the Russians in a great way, their dedication to their service, their competence, but I'm sure I used the word arrogant many, many, many times, and he knew what I was getting at.
I'm sure that his discussion was
Molotov and even Stalin.
I'm sure, well I say I'm sure, I'm really sure that the nature of the discussions, of the air around the discussion was the same as it was for me at my level and in particular General Vandenberg.
Initially General Vandenberg attended all these meetings and I forgot to tell you that they were holding one decision

in advance until, depending on how the conferences went, the whole discussion with Darlene, how open they thought back in Washington that the Russians would be with us and how free our communications would be with one another as to whether it was worthwhile for General Vandenberg, a general, to stay in Russia, or me,
lieutenant colonel whom they knew and planned to promote to full colonel.
And obviously they must have made the decision that, well, we just don't think that it's worthwhile to keep General Vandenberg over there.
And of course they had plans for General Vandenberg and a very great career back home also, being one of General Arnold's white haired boys and a very fine officer.
So at least they felt that Colonel I, Charlie Bond, could do the job for the time being, and of course everybody agreed to this.
So that's the reason General Vandenberg went on the back.
And then in the invasion of North Africa, if you remember, General Vandenberg got a key job in air power.
He and Doolittle and North Africa.
Yeah, absolutely.
Yes, the ambassador and I talked many times, and we came very close.
He called me Charlie, and I would always address him, Mr.
Ambassador.
I had a very healthy respect for him.
I wondered at times about his health.
He always walked in a stooped, with his shoulders sort of a stooped attitude.
But as far as being sharp, mentally sharp, I thought he was terrific.
He never spoke openly to me about
the details of, let's say, a personal discussion with Starling.
I've heard him discuss... Did you ever ask him what kind of man is Starling?
Oh, yes.
As a matter of fact, we, you know, this is the kind of question we're always asking each other.
I felt free to ask, what do you think of Mr. Starling and Mr. Molotov?
And he'd give me, there were never answers that were, showed that there was a
obvious dislike for any of them, but on the other hand, it was very obvious to me that it wasn't an answer that indicated he thought they were terrific people.
I knew he was having problems, and I knew he was having, you know, even discussion problems.
They were very demanding people, and I had an idea that his discussions with them at times were difficult.
How did he answer when you asked him what kind of man is Stalin?
Do you remember?
No, I don't remember exactly, except that he indicated that he was, you know, a very dedicated great man, that type of thing, and had a great, terrific responsibility and a terrific job.
Never anything about a horrible communist, never anything indicating that, never anything about a...
dictator who was killing people, you know, never anything like that.
I don't ever recall him making a comment, really, about a Russian leader that, except that time I was telling you about Molotov, when he walked back and forth and he was obviously dissatisfied.
But that's the only time that you ever remember him making a negative comment about a Russian leader, even though he was going through these torturous negotiations.
He must have had a tremendous amount of control.
He did, with no doubt in my mind.
And I'm sure that's one of the reasons he selected the job.
Because of his dealings, I think it was over magnesium, business dealings in previous years with Russia.
He had been to Russia before and was a businessman.
Of course, he was a diplomat, and I think that's one of the reasons he was chosen by President Roosevelt.
Did Harriman ever make any statements about Roosevelt?

I don't remember any particular statement, but I do know there was a terrific mutual respect there between the two men, and one thing, Harriman and I was, you know, I was privy to the diplomat cables coming back and forth,
Mr. Herman never wasted any time writing to Hull, the Secretary of State.
His bars were always to President Roosevelt.
Direct and no doubt who he worked with.
Did you get to read the cables?
Many of them I did.
Not all of them, of course.
But anything pertaining particularly to the Air Force was a problem.
I was head of the Air Division.
There was a Navy Division, Air, Army, and then Lease.
Navy Commander had the Naval Division, I had the Air Force Division, Army Brigadier General had the Army Division, and a, I think a two-star general, Army Commander, had the Land Legion Division.
And we worked under General Dean, Gus Dean.
Yeah.
And I was wondering about how did the different services, the different branches of the embassy
How well did they work and cooperate on their heroine?
Very well, very well.
Matter of fact, I don't ever remember having any problems from the standpoint of coordination between the services.
There were just no type of problem like that that would have to come up because we weren't involved in tactics.
You know, we weren't fighting combat.
The Navy had their supply functions to
supply, in other words, give supplies and get supplies to Russia by the way of Murmansk and Vladivostok.
And by the way, the chief coordinator for the weather objective, the weather exchange, was a Navy commander.
And that, by the way, turned out very well.
They cooperated.
Well, we're going to talk about all those three things that you wanted to try to accomplish.
There was no problems.
But as far as...
Okay.
Now, Dean was in charge.
He was sort of the chief of staff.
He was the head of the U.S. Military Mission in Russia.
Okay.
Tell me about General Dean.
General Dean was a very fine officer.
I have the utmost respect and admiration for him.
He had a hard job.
He was very much the personality of Mr. Harriman.
Easygoing, soft-spoken,
wore heavy, very heavy spectacles, and had a very keen sense of humor.
I don't know the basic arm that he was trained in in the Army.
He was a major general at the time, but he
He was a fine diplomatic type.
He was a perfect man for that job.
I've seen him many, many more times than I did the Mr. Herman be angry and upset.
And of course we talked.
I had the chance to talk to him more than I did the Ambassador because my office was in his office.
He had
He had a healthy respect for the Russians.
Of course, many of the things I believe about the Russians, you know, stem from our continual relations and discussions.
Many of my feelings, or his feelings, may very well be that he learned some things from me.
You know, I would continue to tell him about my relations with the Russians.
Well, what did he have to say about his?
Looking back and sort of recapping general feelings about the Russians, he respected their combat capability and their dedication to the war effort.

he thought of them in terms of and so did I and we actually saw this on a field visit to the front which I had several rather primitive in their efforts of supply and organization but nevertheless and I emphasize this nevertheless very effective in combat because they to quote their
statement.
We killed Germans.
We killed Germans.
In that respect, we had a great deal of admiration and respect for the Russians.
I should think that, of course, they were fighting on their own soil.
This made quite a difference.
Can you imagine visiting Americans fighting, let's say, on
caught in the United States someplace, an invader, can you imagine the spirit that you would see there?
Well, this is what we saw in Russia.
In spite of that, however, I still say that a war between Russia and the United States and actually locked in combat on ground, sea, or air.
